Russell_Dickerson:
{{short description|American singer-songwriter}} {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2019}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Russell Dickerson | image = Russell Dickerson 2023 Headshot.jpg | image_size = | caption = Dickerson in 2023 | alt = A head shot of singer Russell Dickerson | birth_name = Russell Edward Dickerson | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1987|05|07}} | birth_place = [[Union City, Tennessee]] | origin = | genre = [[Country pop]]{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/russell-dickerson-mn0002948894/biography|title=Russell Dickerson – Biography & History|website=[[AllMusic]]}} | occupation = Singer-songwriter | instrument = Vocals | years_active = 2011–present | label = Triple Tigers | website = {{URL|www.russelldickerson.com/}} }} '''Russell Edward Dickerson''' (born May 7, 1987) is an American [[country pop]] singer-songwriter from [[Union City, Tennessee]].{{cite web|last=Erlewine|first=Stephen Thomas|authorlink1=Stephen Thomas Erlewine|title=Russell Dickerson {{!}} Biography & History|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=mn0002948894/biography|pure_url=yes}}|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=May 13, 2016}} Dickerson has released two albums through [[Triple Tigers]]. Both have accounted for four singles charting on [[Hot Country Songs]] and [[Country Airplay]]: "[[Yours (Russell Dickerson song)|Yours]]", "[[Blue Tacoma]]", "[[Every Little Thing (Russell Dickerson song)|Every Little Thing]]", and "[[Love You Like I Used To]]". ==Biography== Russell Edward Dickerson was born May 7, 1987, in [[Union City, Tennessee]]. He earned a bachelor's degree in music from [[Belmont University]] and signed with [[Creative Artists Agency]] in 2010. In 2011, he released an [[extended play]], ''Die to Live Again'', and opened for [[David Nail]].{{cite news|last1=Freeman|first1=Jon|title=Review: David Nail Sells Out Exit/In|url=http://www.musicrow.com/2011/07/review-david-nail-sells-out-exitin/|access-date=May 13, 2016|work=[[MusicRow]]|date=July 29, 2011}} He toured with [[Canaan Smith]] in 2015,{{cite news|last1=McClellan|first1=Laura|title=Canaan Smith Embarking on First Headlining Tour|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/canaan-smith-headlining-tour-dates-2015/|access-date=May 13, 2016|work=[[Taste of Country]]|date=September 18, 2015}} and [[Thomas Rhett]] in the summer of 2016. Dickerson also joined [[Billy Currington]] on the road in 2016. In 2015, he released the single "Yours" written by Dickerson, Parker Welling, and Casey Brown.{{cite news|last1=Liebig|first1=Lorie|title=Rising Artist Russell Dickerson on How Perseverance Shaped His Sound|url=http://www.wideopencountry.com/russell-dickerson-interview/|access-date=May 13, 2016|work=Wide Open Country|date=February 19, 2016}} It became the title track to his second extended play, released on January 18, 2016, by Dent Records.{{cite web|last=Erlewine|first=Stephen Thomas|authorlink1=Stephen Thomas Erlewine|title=''Yours EP'' review|url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=mw0002913502|pure_url=yes}}|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=May 13, 2016}} The EP debuted at number 14 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Top Country Albums chart, selling 2,700 copies in its first week of release.{{cite news|last1=Bjorke|first1=Matt|title=Country Album Sales Chart: January 25, 2016|url=http://roughstock.com/news/2016/01/39645-country-album-sales-chart-january-25-2016|access-date=May 13, 2016|work=Roughstock|date=January 23, 2016}} It launched at number 2 in the iTunes Country Store and number 8 in all genres.{{cite web|url=https://www.russelldickerson.com/about/|title=About|website=Russell Dickerson Official Site}} On October 10, 2016, he signed with Triple Tigers Records which assumed distribution of the single.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/nashville/news/2016/10/11/thirty-tigers-triple-8-management-and-sony-music.html|title=Thirty Tigers, Triple 8 Management and Sony Music partner on new country label|last=Snyder|first=Eric|date=October 11, 2016|work=Nashville Business Journal|access-date=May 30, 2018}} In its 39th week on [[Billboard (magazine)|''Billboard's'']] Country Airplay chart, Dickerson jumped from number 3 to 1 on the list on January 27, 2018.{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/8095688/russell-dickerson-yours-country-airplay-number-one-triple-tigers-records|title=Russell Dickerson & Triple Tigers Records Roar To First Country Airplay No. 1 With 'Yours'|magazine=Billboard|access-date=30 May 2018}} The album, ''Yours'' was released on October 13, 2017, and premiered at No. 1 on [[Billboard (magazine)|''Billboard's'']]'' Heat Seeker chart. ''The album peaked at No. 5 on Top Country Albums dated November 4, 2017, with 12,000 equivalent album units in its first week'', ''and includes five songs co-written by Dickerson, containing an acoustic wedding version of the title track "Yours."{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/8095688/russell-dickerson-yours-country-airplay-number-one-triple-tigers-records|title=Russell Dickerson & Triple Tigers Records Roar To First Country Airplay No. 1 With 'Yours'|magazine=Billboard|access-date=31 May 2018}} Due to the popularity of his hit single, he landed on the iTunes Best of 2015 year-end list, TheKnot.com's "Best Wedding Songs of 2016," and [[Spotify]]'s #SpotifySpotlight 2016; where he later became one of Spotify's RISE artists.{{Cite news|url=http://www.russelldickerson.com/about/|title=About |work=Russell Dickerson Official Site|access-date=30 May 2018}} Dickerson made his [[Grand Ole Opry]] debut on June 3, 2016.{{Cite news|url=https://www.allaccess.com/country/industry-snap/q/id/516683|title=Russell Dickerson, Grand Ole Opry, Yours, Pete Fisher, Russell Dickerson, SiriusXM, JR ...|work=All Access|access-date=30 May 2018}} An album also titled ''Yours'' produced two additional singles in "[[Blue Tacoma]]" and "[[Every Little Thing (Russell Dickerson song)|Every Little Thing]]", which topped the Country Airplay charts as well. Dickerson's second album, ''[[Southern Symphony]]'', came out in late 2020 on Triple Tigers. Its lead single, "[[Love You Like I Used To]]", also went to number one on the country music charts. Dickerson and [[Tyler Hubbard]] were both featured on [[Thomas Rhett]]'s 2022 song "[[Death Row (Thomas Rhett song)|Death Row]]".{{cite news |last1=Wendowski |first1=Andrew |title=Thomas Rhett, Tyler Hubbard & Russell Dickerson's New Song "Death Row" Is Based On A True Story |url=https://musicmayhemmagazine.com/listen-thomas-rhett-tyler-hubbard-russell-dickersons-new-song-death-row-is-based-on-a-true-story/ |access-date=15 May 2022 |publisher=Music Mayhem Magazine |date=March 4, 2022}} On June 27, 2023, Dickerson released his third EP ''Three Months Two Streets Down''.{{cite web|url=https://musicrow.com/2023/06/russell-dickerson-releases-summer-ep-celebrates-with-party-at-pearl-diver|title=Russell Dickerson Releases Summer EP, Celebrates With Party At Pearl Diver|author=LB Cantrell|publisher=Music Row|date=June 29, 2023|access-date=July 5, 2023}} ==Personal life== Dickerson married his wife, Kailey, on May 5, 2013. On September 10, 2020, the couple's first child was born.{{Cite web|url=https://people.com/parents/russell-dickerson-shares-first-photos-son-remington-wife-kailey/|title = Meet Remington Edward! Russell Dickerson Introduces Newborn Son — See the Adorable First Photos}} On October 1, 2023, their second son was born.{{cite web|url=https://949thebull.iheart.com/content/2023-10-07-russell-dickerson-wife-kailey-welcome-baby-no-2-see-the-first-photos|title=Russell Dickerson & Wife Kailey Welcome Baby No. 2 — See The First Photos|author=Kelly Fisher|publisher=94.9 The Bull|date=October 7, 2023|access-date=October 7, 2023}} ==Discography== {{Infobox artist discography | Studio = 3 | Compilation = | Live = | EP = 3 | Singles = 9 | Music videos = 5 | Option = 4 | Option name = No. 1 singles }} ===Studio albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! scope="col" rowspan="2" style="width:10em;"| Title ! scope="col" rowspan="2" style="width:18em;"| Album details ! scope="col" colspan="3"| Peak chart positions ! scope="col" rowspan="2" style="width:10em;"| [[List of music recording certifications|Certifications]] ! scope="col" rowspan="2" style="width:9em;"| Sales |- style="font-size:smaller;" ! scope="col" style="width:4em;"| [[Billboard 200|US]]

(with Jake Scott) | |} ==Tours== '''Supporting''' *[[David Nail]] (2011) *[[Canaan Smith]] (2015) *[[Billy Currington]] (2016) *[[Home Team Tour]] (2017) {{small|(Select Dates)}} with [[Thomas Rhett]] *Life Changes Tour (2018) (Select Dates) with [[Thomas Rhett]] *Summer Plays on Tour (2018) with [[Lady A]] and [[Darius Rucker]] *Very Hot Summer Tour (2019) with [[Thomas Rhett]] *Worldwide Beautiful Tour (2020) with [[Kane Brown]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://www.russelldickerson.net/}} {{Russell Dickerson}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dickerson, Russell}} [[Category:1987 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American country singer-songwriters]] [[Category:American male singer-songwriters]] [[Category:American tenors]] [[Category:Belmont University alumni]] [[Category:Country musicians from Tennessee]] [[Category:Singers from Nashville, Tennessee]] [[Category:Singer-songwriters from Tennessee]] [[Category:People from Union City, Tennessee]] [[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]] [[Category:21st-century American male singers]] [[Category:Thirty Tigers artists]]
